frontmatter.title: Add Configurable Navigation Bar To Gatsby Blog

node.excerpt: A common practice when hiring a new developer is to have them complete a practical coding test. This can be completed via a take home project. Often however, the developer is asked to complete a practical code test during the interview. While I understand why this happens, I don’t believe setting up an adversarial situation during the interview process is ideal when hiring a new candidate. That said, it is a fact of life we as developers have to work through. As such it is a great idea to complete regular programmatic challenges as part of our interview preparation. Today, I decided to remake the Array.map function using promises for just a such a challenge.

frontmatter.title: Add Publish Flag To Posts In Gatsby
frontmatter.description: The first thing I wanted to do after setting up this new blog using the Gatsby Starter Project is to make it possible to only display posts that I wanted to show. There are for sure going to be times where I want to work on a series of posts over time that I can also version, but not have them show on my live site until I am ready. This is where I first started learning about frontmatter and how to query it using GraphQL in the Gatsby blog.

node.excerpt: It may be a bit odd as someone who has worked professionally making and hosting WordPress websites to create a blog using a different tool. WordPress is a fantastic tool, and truly is a wonderful tool for creating all manner of websites from blogs to e-commerce sites. That said, with the focus of this blog being more about my personal growth using JavaScript and mobile technologies it seems only fitting I use a tool based largely on that. But there is more to the story.

frontmatter.title: Why I Am Using Gatsby For This Blog
How To Deploy A Gatsby Blog To Github Pages

node.excerpt: I have written many blog posts on different blogs in the past. This time however, I am starting a new adventure using tools that are largely new to me. While I have worked with raw JavaScript, and JavaScript based tools for about 20 years, Gatsby is a brand new world to me. It combines much of what I already know with new technologies I am actively working to master such as Node, React and GraphQL. Working with a complete focus of direction to living and breathing JavaScript based technologies coupled with a focus on proper work management via remote work and asynchronous communication, to say I am excited is an understatement.
